absorb.translation[0].definitions[0].def: to take in liquid, gas, or another substance from the surface or space around something
absorb.translation[0].definitions[0].exa: Plants absorb nutrients from the soil.
Water and salts are absorbed into our bloodstream.
absorb.translation[0].definitions[1].def: to read or hear a large amount of new information and understand it
absorb.translation[0].definitions[1].exa: Her capacity to absorb information is amazing.
absorb.translation[0].definitions[2].def: to interest someone so much that they do not pay attention to other things
absorb.translation[0].definitions[2].exa: The movement and noise of the machines absorbed him completely.
Judith lay on the settee, absorbed in her book.
absorb.translation[0].definitions[3].def: to become part of something larger
absorb.translation[0].definitions[3].exa: California absorbs many of the legal immigrants to the US.
We were soon absorbed into local village life.
absorb.translation[0].definitions[4].def: if something absorbs light, heat, energy, or noise, it takes it in
absorb.translation[0].definitions[5].def: if something absorbs changes or costs, it accepts them and deals with them successfully
absorb.translation[0].definitions[5].exa: The beer industry had absorbed a doubling of federal tax in 1991.
absorb.translation[0].definitions[6].def: if something absorbs money, time etc, it uses a lot of it
absorb.translation[0].definitions[6].exa: Defence spending absorbs almost 20% of the country’s wealth.
absorb.translation[0].definitions[7].def: to reduce the effect of a sudden violent movement
absorb.translation[0].definitions[7].exa: A well-designed sports shoe should absorb the impact on your feet.
absorb.translation[1].definitions[0].def: if a large organization absorbs a smaller one, it takes control of it and makes it part of the organization
absorb.translation[1].definitions[0].exa: The company was absorbed by IBM in 1995.
Several smaller companies were absorbed into the group.
absorb.translation[1].definitions[1].def: if a business absorbs costs, it is able to deal with them without any bad effects
absorb.translation[1].definitions[1].exa: Careful cost control has allowed the bank to absorb the costs of the merger.
absorb.translation[1].definitions[2].def: if a market absorbs a product, it accepts it and is able to sell it
absorb.translation[1].definitions[2].exa: Canada absorbs about 23% of US exports.
Trading was cautious and quiet as the market prepared to absorb £55 billion of government securities to be sold this week.
absorb.translation[1].definitions[3].def: if something absorbs money or time, it uses a lot of it
absorb.translation[1].definitions[3].exa: Defence spending absorbs almost 20% of the country’s wealth.
